abstracts.cdata!:
The Provincial Health Sector Development
            Project is rated as unsatisfactory, sustainability as
            unlikely, institutional development impact as modest, Bank
            performance as unsatisfactory, and borrower performance as
            unsatisfactory. The economic recession experienced by
            Argentina from 1998 until project closure had a significant
            negative impact on construction firms, which in turn
            affected project implementation. Procurement problems and
            architectural problems also caused delays. Key lessons
            learned from the implementation of the project include: 1)
            The Bank should encourage the Borrower to request a
            reformulation of a project if and when it becomes clear that
            the development objectives are no longer feasible. 2)
            Operations requiring provincial commitments should obtain
            those commitments before project approval. 3) A reform is a
            political process first, and only later a technical process.
            It requires on both a creation of the political viability
            and development of technical feasibility. 4) In a
            reform-oriented project, investment in civil works should be
            made contingent on adoption of specific changes in the
            sectoral "software" (e.g., management, human
            resources, or the other subjects of the reform). 5) Intense
            supervision is crucial for smooth project implementation,
            particularly in the face of political turbulence.
